Award.AwardTitle: A University Consortium for Interdisciplinary Water Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Science, Inc. (CUAHSI) will build on its existing Water Data Center (WDC) facility to provide a range of services to the multidisciplinary water science community. Specifically, CUAHSI will offer training in instrumentation and host specialty conferences in field instrumentation and hydroinformatics. CUAHSI will continue its successful activities from the past, including Pathfinder graduate student travel grants, Research Cyberseminars, Let's Talk about Water outreach events, and the Biennial Water Science Symposia. A new initiative is the development of a community governance process and community modeling resources designed to enable the water science community to more readily contribute its knowledge of continental water processes to Earth Systems models. This will be a collaborative effort with NCAR to develop a water-oriented branch of the Community Land Model (CLM), that would be supported by the Water Data Center, and empower the community toward improving the model realism in large-scale water storages and fluxes in climate and Earth system simulations. Strategic planning activities are incorporated into the core governance of CUAHSI.

Because water connects the biotic and abiotic components of the Earth system and is a critical economic and ecological resource, CUAHSI services impact multiple disciplines and serve society at large. The WDC will enable new synthetic research, and better sharing and dissemination of research data and results that can be utilized in applied and policy research. The advancement of standards for water data ensures free and better exchange of information between academics, federal agencies and the private sector. CUAHSI Hydrologic Information System is being used by multiple governments around the world (the Dominican Republic and the Republic of Italy). The WDC will also target outreach activities to the Native American community through tribal colleges and tribal government. Water management is a major issue at many reservations and water science provides an attractive career path for Native Americans with jobs available at all degree levels. Training and outreach activities will provide important training and research opportunities for graduate students to explore meaningful and important interdisciplinary questions. Advancement of water science depends on such investments in part because of the many traditional disciplines that are required for an understanding of water in the Earth system. CUAHSI seeks to overcome fragmentation in water science research by supporting interdisciplinary science. The services included in this project have been selected to provide maximum benefit to the community as well as to serve as a foundation for the advancement of the science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Science, Inc. (CUAHSI) had a major impact on the hydrologic science community, building community through training, meetings, seminars, and other outreach efforts. CUAHSI’s Water Data Services provide critical infrastructure for the community by building and maintaining technology that allows anyone to discover, share, and publish water data, models, and other types of information. Key outcomes for the project period are summarized below.

  1. The HydroClient (HIS) map interface with filters for discovering and downloading time-series data was developed and implemented. See http://data.cuahsi.org/.
  2. The HIS system averages about 300 users per month, although usage in 2018 (5,498 users) was more than double that in 2016 (2,524).
  3. A time-series data uploader for HIS was improved as requested by the user community.
  4. CUAHSI assumed operation of HydroShare (https://www.hydroshare.org/landingPage/). Downtime was reduced significantly: whereas upgrades used to take several hours, new versions now are released with very limited (less than 5 minutes) downtime. More than 500 bug fixes and enhancements were addressed by the CUAHSI team.
  5. HydroShare growth is continuing, and among some user types growth is accelerating. HydroShare currently has more than 5,500 total users.
  6. CUAHSI rolled out compute services, including the ability to launch Jupyter notebooks and MATLAB within the CUAHSI computing environment. MATLAB is a proprietary software requiring a license and fees, but CUAHSI's partnership with MathWorks makes this software freely available to the hydrologic sciences community.
  7. CUAHSI created new functionality in HydroShare to support data management by the Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) community. All metadata from all ten CZOs have been migrated to HydroShare, and CZO data managers are nearing completion of migration of their data into HydroShare.
  8. CUAHSI HydroShare was adopted by the U.S. State Department as a data management solution for the Mekong Water Data Initiative. http://data.mekongwater.org/. CUAHSI provided training to the Mekong River Commission in Vientiane, Laos, and to Vietnamese university researchers in CUAHSI’s Cambridge office.
  9. CUAHSI is mentioned in 997 products found in Google Scholar for the project period, indicating a broad and growing scientific impact.
  10. CUAHSI provide 126 letters of support during the project. Most of these letters were for proposals to NSF in which the PIs planned to use CUAHSI's Water Data Services for data management or CUAHSI's Community Services to engage with the broader community. At least 35 of the proposals were funded, which is at a success rate greater than the average for NSF proposals.
  11. CUAHSI launched the CUAHSI Virtual University in 2017. This unique program, to our knowledge, is the first program of its kind, in which students take modules from instructors at a variety of universities and receive credit at their home institution.
  12. In partnership with NOAA and the National Water Center (NWC), CUAHSI launched the Summer Institute, which is a valuable 7-week residential research experience at the NWC with a focus on improving the National Water Model.
  13. CUAHSI sponsored 89 cyberseinars and 39 in-person workshops. CUAHSI ssued 493 travel grants to students attending CUAHSI workshops.
  14. CUAHSI's web site was entirely revamped in 2017 leading to increased access.
  15. CUAHSI's social media presence and uptake grew significantly during with a >250 percent in CUAHSI newsletter subscriptions.
  16. CUAHSI supported at least four NSF Hydrologic Sciences workshops: a WSC PI workshop in 2017 and 2018, an INFEWS PI workshop in 2018, and the IHTM workshop in 2019.

CUAHSI hosted 89 cyberseminar and publishes cyberseminars on YouTube, which allows the community continued access to the more than 200 recordings. During 2015 -2019, the number of unique views of CUAHSI cyberseminars was 27,935, with almost 90 percent (25,072) of those views from CUAHSI's YouTube channel.

CUAHSI Virtual University (CVU) was launched in Fall 2017, at the recommendation of the CUAHSI Standing Committee on Outreach and Education. The CVU is an innovative program of inter-university online modules taught synchronously faculty in specialized research niches from across the country. The CVU aims to enhance the depth and breadth of graduate course offerings at universities, increase the rate of uptake of new research, and facilitate networking among both students and faculty. Six modules were taught for Fall 2017 (44 participants), eight modules were taught in Fall 2018 (58 participants).

CUAHSI sponsored 39 in-person workshops during 2015 - 2019, with a total of 710 participants. A listing of past workshops can be viewed at https://www.cuahsi.org/education/training/past-trainings-and-workshops/.

The CUAHSI Summer Institute (SI) held at the National Water Center (NWC) was developed during the reporting period. The SI provides graduate students with a seven-week residential research experience at the NWC. A total of 146 students from 77 unique institutions participated in the SI during 2015 - 2019, and student projects are summarized in technical reports in a Featured Collections of the Journal of the American Water Resources.
